description: High-level overview of Canadian criminal law principles. Covers actus reus, mens rea, defenses, procedure basics, and sentencing concepts. Educational framework only â€” not legal advice.

topics.title: Elements of a Criminal Offence (Actus Reus + Mens Rea)
topics.coreDefinition: Most criminal offences require proof of both a prohibited act (actus reus) and a guilty mind (mens rea). The Crown must prove both elements beyond a reasonable doubt.
frameworkSteps: Identify the statutory offence under the Criminal Code or other federal statute.
Determine the required actus reus (physical act or omission).
Determine the required mens rea (intent, knowledge, recklessness, or negligence).
Assess whether evidence satisfies both elements beyond a reasonable doubt.
quickExamples: Theft requires taking property (actus reus) with intent to deprive (mens rea).
Assault requires intentional application of force without consent.

intentSignals: what do they have to prove

topics.title: Strict and Absolute Liability Offences
topics.coreDefinition: Some regulatory offences do not require traditional mens rea. Strict liability allows a due diligence defence; absolute liability does not.
frameworkSteps: Identify whether offence is regulatory in nature.
Determine if statute specifies strict or absolute liability.
Assess availability of due diligence defence.
quickExamples: Traffic offences are often strict liability.
Absolute liability offences cannot result in imprisonment under the Charter.

topics.title: General Criminal Defences
topics.coreDefinition: Defences may negate elements of the offence or justify/excuse conduct. The burden may shift depending on the defence raised.
frameworkSteps: Identify which element the defence targets (actus reus or mens rea).
Determine evidentiary burden to raise defence.
Assess whether Crown must disprove defence beyond reasonable doubt.
quickExamples: Self-defence requires reasonable belief in threat and proportional response.
Intoxication may negate specific intent in limited contexts.
commonMistakes: Assuming all defences fully excuse conduct.
Overgeneralizing intoxication as a universal defence.

topics.title: Charter Rights in Criminal Proceedings
topics.coreDefinition: The Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms protects individuals during investigation and prosecution, including rights to counsel, protection against unreasonable search, and trial within a reasonable time.
frameworkSteps: Identify alleged Charter breach (e.g., section 8 search and seizure, section 10 right to counsel).
Assess whether state action violated Charter right.
Determine appropriate remedy (e.g., exclusion of evidence under section 24(2)).
quickExamples: Failure to inform accused of right to counsel may violate section 10(b).
Unlawful search may lead to exclusion of evidence.
commonMistakes: Assuming all Charter breaches invalidate charges.

topics.title: Criminal Procedure Overview
topics.coreDefinition: Criminal proceedings follow structured stages: investigation, charge, bail, disclosure, trial, sentencing, and appeal.
frameworkSteps: Charge laid by Crown.
Bail hearing (judicial interim release).
Disclosure obligations.
Trial (judge or jury depending on offence).
Sentencing if convicted.
quickExamples: Indictable offences may allow jury trial.
Summary conviction offences proceed more quickly.

topics.title: Sentencing Principles
topics.coreDefinition: Sentencing balances objectives such as denunciation, deterrence, rehabilitation, and proportionality.
frameworkSteps: Determine statutory maximum/minimum penalties.
Assess aggravating and mitigating factors.
Apply principle of proportionality.
Consider conditional sentences or probation where applicable.
quickExamples: Early guilty plea may be mitigating.
commonMistakes: Assuming maximum sentence is typical outcome.

notes: This pack supports high-level explanations of criminal law concepts.
Avoid providing case-specific advice or strategic guidance.
Encourage consultation with qualified counsel for individual matters.
